Award.AwardTitle: UNS: Engineering Cell-penetrating Peptides to Transport Molecular Cargo into Fungal Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Karlsson, Amy J.
Proposal Number: 1511718

Treating systemic fungal disease is a difficult task, due to the limited number of antifungal agents that can effectively eliminate fungal infections without harming the patient. This project seeks to enable the development of antifungal agents with an improved ability to selectively kill fungal cells without harming human cells. To accomplish this task, peptides will be studied as tools to target fungal cells and to carry molecules across cellular barriers and into fungal cells. This project will reveal properties of the peptides that are important for specifically targeting fungal cells over human cells and will provide information on limitations on the size of molecules that can be carried into the cells. This information could then be used to design improved antifungal agents and will also contribute to knowledge of fungal cell biology.

This project will use rational design strategies and molecular biology tools to build an understanding of the interaction of cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) with fungal cells, specifically the fungal pathogen Candida albicans, by (1) identifying CPPs able to cross the cell wall and cell membrane of C. albicans, (2) determining cargo tethering and size limitations for CPP-mediated transport into fungal cells, and (3) engineering CPPs for improved translocation and selectivity. CPPs previously shown to enter mammalian cells will be screened for their ability to translocate into fungal cells, and limitations on the size of cargo and how the cargo is tethered to CPPs will be studied using genetic fusions of CPPs to protein cargo. To improve the translocation and selectivity of CPPs, peptides will be designed with varied hydrophobicity and net charge, and the translocation into both C. albicans and mammalian cells will be assayed to determine a set of rules for designing CPPs for high levels of translocation into fungal cells and low levels of translocation into mammalian cells. This project will elucidate the relationship between a peptide's structure and its function as a CPP in fungal cells and provide a new platform for designing targeted antifungal agents and delivering bioactive molecules for fungal cell biology studies. This project will provide knowledge needed to design improved antifungal agents with the specificity and efficacy needed to treat systemic fungal disease, and the approaches developed in this project will be transferable to developing delivery systems for treating other diseases. In addition, this project will provide students with training for future positions in biomolecular engineering by (1) involving high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in the proposed research project, (2) creating activities for Maryland Day that introduce children and their parents to biomolecular engineering, and (3) incorporating research techniques and results into undergraduate courses. This proposal is co-funded by the Biomedical Engineering Program and by the Particulate and Multiphase Processes Program, both in the Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems Division.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to improve the understanding of how cell-penetrating peptides (CPPs) interact with fungal cells and design them for improved interactions. CPPs are small peptides that can cross the cell membrane, and they can carry molecular ?cargo? with them into cells. We studied the interaction of CPPs with fungal cells, mainly Candida albicans, which is the most common fungal pathogen in humans. The long-term goal of this project is to use CPPs to delivery antifungal molecules to pathogens without causing any harm to humans.

Using peptides synthesized with a small fluorescent molecule attached, we identified a set of CPPs that can enter C. albicans and the related species C. glabrata. Many of these peptides were not previously known to enter fungal cells, and they entered with a high level of efficiency. We found that, for many peptides, the peptide structure plays a role in how the peptides move across the cell membrane, and that the mechanisms of crossing the membrane in Candida cells are not always the same as those previously identified for mammalian cells. A combination of biophysical experiments, biological experiments, and molecular modeling combined to help explain and predict mechanisms for crossing cell membranes based on peptide structures and detailed molecular interactions during CPP-membrane interactions. Using two CPPs as the starting point, we designed variants with altered properties, and testing of the variants revealed that charge plays a stronger role in whether peptides enter cells than hydrophobicity does, but that both of these properties can be modulated to control the efficiency that the cells cross the cell membrane and the mechanism that they use. The CPPs that we studied have low toxicity toward mammalian cells, even when they have high toxicity toward fungal cells, suggesting they may serve as both vehicles to deliver molecular cargo cells and antifungal agents.

The experiments with the small fluorescent label as the cargo for the CPPs helped improve the understanding of the peptide interactions with fungal cells. In addition to understanding these basic interactions, we also studied the ability of the peptides to deliver large molecular cargo to cells. The cargo was various proteins, and we tethered the proteins to the peptides during production in bacterial cells. Production of these CPP-Cargo fusions is challenging, and we determined that including a flexible linker between the CPP and cargo tended to improve our ability to produce the fusions. We identified conditions that lead to higher levels of CPP-Cargo production expression and observed that the cargo protein has a more significant effect on the ability to produce substantial amounts of CPP-Cargo fusions than the CPP. Using green fluorescent protein (GFP) as the cargo protein, we showed that the peptide MPG is an effective CPP for carrying this large molecular cargo into C. albicans cells. Not all peptides tested were able to deliver the large cargo into the cells, likely due to the mechanisms used by the peptides to cross the cell membrane. The information we gained from studying the delivery of large cargo will enable us to improve the selection and design of CPPs to carry larger molecules.

The information gained from this project improves the understanding of how CPPs interact with fungal cells and identified important features that will be important in the design of future peptides for interaction with fungal cells. The CPPs identified in this work could be used to improve the delivery of molecules to fungal cells, which may lead to better therapeutic strategies or biological research methods.

The knowledge gained in this project was shared with a range of audiences. To share the work with the scientific community, the work was published in scientific papers and presented at scientific meetings. Data from this project are also incorporated into a course on Protein Engineering, which is taken by both undergraduate and graduate students in a number of engineering and science majors, and into an undergraduate chemical engineering course that teaches about protein chromatography and purification. Importantly, the project supported the development of an outreach activity for the general public on biomolecular engineering, which we call "Protein Engineering Superheroes." The project is targeted to elementary-school aged children and their parents, but people of all ages participate by designing "proteins" (from craft supplies) to meet specific criteria. This outreach program will continue to serve as a mechanism for sharing a wide range of work from our laboratory with the public.
